The problem is about Stanley traveling between cities with roads and flights. The key point is that he can take at most k flights.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: The goal is to find the minimum time to each city from city 1, considering that flights between any two cities u and v take (u - v)^2 time, but he can use at most k of them.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: The newdp[i] would be the minimum between its current value (from roads) and (dp[j] + (i-j)^2) for all j. But considering all j would be O(n^2), which is too big. Hence, the convex hull trick is used here to optimize this. The line added to the CHT is for each j, the line a = -2j, b = dp[j] + j². Then for a given i, the query would compute the minimum over all j of (a * i + b) = -2j*i + dp[j] + j². Which simplifies to ( -2ij + j² ) + dp[j], which is j² - 2ij + i² - i² + dp[j] + j²? So, when you take the CHT, the term involving i is linear in i, so the lines for each j are a = -2j, b = dp[j] + j². Then the minimum over all j of (a * i + b) gives the minimal ( -2j*i + (dp[j] +j²) ), which when added to i² gives the minimal (dp[j] + (i-j)^2). Hence, the CHT is used to compute the minimal (dp[j] + (i-j)^2) for each i by querying the CHT at x=i. Then, the newdp[i] would be the minimum between the current newdp[i] and that value.
